text:
It’s a Tuesday. 
 
It’s a  Tuesday.  Things don't happen on Tuesdays. They just  don't. Tuesday is, and always has been, the least eventful day of the week. 
 
So  why  is there a  thing happening?
 
“I’m Eraserhead!” The vigilante, small and green, and looking distinctly unlike his namesake, pipes up brightly.
 
Aizawa Shouta, also known as Eraserhead the pro hero, stares. 
 
“No,” he says, eventually. “I don’t think you are.”
 
“I  am,” the vigilante insists. “I know pros aren’t supposed to have the same codenames as each other, but  I’m not a pro. So it’s okay.”
 
It’s  not  okay. Eraserhead—the  real  Eraserhead—is an  underground  hero. Civilians don’t  know  what Aizawa actually looks like, so when this little demon helps them out, calling himself by that name, Aizawa ends up getting the credit.
 
Essentially, Eraserhead-the-vigilante is getting away, near flawlessly, with acts of vigilantism.
 
It’s  almost  ingenious. Except for the part where the little terror thought Aizawa just  wouldn’t notice  the pay rise he’s been getting due to numerous accounts of heroism that he hasn't performed.
 
“My intel says you like logical ruses,” the kid, because there’s no way he  isn’t a goddamn brat, explains.
 
And intel? What  intel? Which one of his students—?
 
 “This isn’t a logical ruse,” Aizawa is feeling more than a little irate. “You’ve stolen my identity.”
 
“No I haven’t!” the hellspawn waves his hands in a flurry. “You can’t just call dibs on a  name,  Eraser! Imagine if I went around demanding that new mothers  not call their child Izuku because it’s my—” he cuts himself off, hurriedly clamping his mouth shut, “....oops.”
 
 Well. That was easier than expected. Apparently the kid likes to talk.
 
“So yeah, anyway, I gotta go. My mum wanted me back by—oh  shit. I mean—just forget I said—anyway, bye Eraserhead!”
 
And then the problem child vanishes suddenly and without any prior warning.
 
Aizawa has a sudden urge to bang his head against a wall for three hours straight. 
 
On a damn  Tuesday. 
 

 Problem child.

 
 
Aizawa has a headache. 
 
The headache is standing three feet away from him, balanced on the edge of the rooftop with a bottle of spray paint in one hand and a tub of glitter in the other.
 
Aizawa raises a single eyebrow.
 
The headache shifts guiltily. “I swear this isn’t what it looks like.”
 
Aizawa raises his  other eyebrow.
 
“Okay, so  maybe  it  is  what it looks like, just a little, but he  deserves it!” 
 
In all honesty, though Aizawa doesn’t know exactly  what  Endeavor did to deserve having his agency redecorated so…  vibrantly,  he doesn’t doubt the validity of the vigilante’s claim. Endeavor’s always got his hands stuck into  something  shady, and Aizawa can probably list a number of possible grievances the kid could be talking about off the top of his head.
 
However…
 
“That may be so, but you  signed it, problem child.”
 
Aizawa isn’t certain, because of the brilliant green mask the brat sports, but he thinks the kid might actually be glaring at him. “Don’t be rude, Eraser; and I don’t see how that’s a problem.”
 
“With your  vigilante  name.”  Damn it, Aizawa needs a drink. Or coffee. Preferably both. He’ll probably end up at a bar before morning, at any rate.
 
“Well  obviously.” There’s an eyeroll there, Aizawa just knows it. “I wasn’t exactly going to expose my real identity, was I? That would just be  stupid.”
 
As if he hasn’t  already exposed half of his damn identity to Aizawa. He just needs a family name, now, though something tells him he’s not going to get it.
 
And speaking of  identities... 
 
“They’re going to think it was  me.”  
 
Of course, nobody will actually believe that Aizawa spray painted his hero name in bright pink letters on the front of Endeavor’s agency, but he’ll  definitely  be interrogated over it, and that means  time  and  energy  and  paperwork. 
 
There’s also the fact that clearing his name of this will mean implicating the child in front of him, which will also mean bringing Endeavor’s wrath down on a  teenager,  and Aizawa wouldn’t wish  that  even on the most irritating of his students, let alone on a kid who’s obviously just trying to do a bit of good, even if he  is going about it in the wrong way.
 
“That,” The  good kid  points at him lazily. “Sounds a lot like a  you problem, Eraserhead.”
 
Aizawa’s final thread of patience  snaps, and he takes a step forward. “You little—”
 
“Hey, is that Endeavor?”
 
Aizawa whirls around to nothing but empty air. He knows that if he looks back he’ll find the same thing; there’s just no use trying, at this point. 
 
He knows he should probably call it in. 
 
 But he also knows that there’s an all-night bar three blocks from here. Mic is always up for a drink.
 
And he needs a fucking drink.
 
He’ll call Tsukauchi in the morning.
 
 
“After-school team up, Eraser, whaddya say?”
 
“No.”
 

 “Yes.” 

 
“Absolutely not.”
 
“Shouta,” Mic whines, like the child he is. “C’mon, man. I wanna meet my nephew!”
 
Aizawa slams the drawer he’d been rifling through shut with a loud bang. “I said no,” he pauses momentarily as Hizashi’s words catch up with him. “And he is not my kid.”
 
“You know, I think you might’ve said something,” Mic saunters up to him, a shit eating grin spanning the entire width of his face. “But all I’m hearing is  denial, Eraserhead.”
 
Aizawa folds his arms, hellbent on sticking to his guns. “No means no, Mic.”
 
“I’ll wear you down by the end of the day.”
 
“Ha. Good luck with  that.”
 
 
“I cannot  believe you talked me into this.”
 
“Oh hush, you,” Mic waves a hand vaguely in Aizawa’s direction. “I’d have come either way, dude. I don’t usually get the chance to work underground, y’know! My quirk’s a little  loud,  I guess—”
 
“Keep your voice down,” Aizawa cuts off his babbling, hissing like a disgruntled cat from their perch on the edge of the rooftop. “I only said you could patrol with me. We’re not hunting for vigilantes.”
 
 “You’re  not hunting for vigilantes,” Mic amends. “I totally am. I’m super hyped to meet one of my little listeners!”
 
“One of your—” Aizawa turns, suspicion suddenly flooding through his system as he glares at his friend. “How do you know he listens to your show?”
 
Mic  freezes. 
 

 Oh no. 

 
“What,” Aizawa grinds out, in equal parts dread and honest-to-god  fear. “Did you  do, Yamada?”
 
Dread, because knowing Mic, the answer could range from mildly amusing to utterly disastrous.
 
Fear, because knowing the  vigilante  in question, disaster is almost a given.
 
“I  may  have let slip on air that I was patrolling tonight with a certain unnamed underground hero, and that if there  were  any copycat vigilantes running around, I’d be happy to sign an autograph for them,” Mic squeaks at the look Aizawa directs at him. “Please don’t kill me.”
 
“You  bribed the kid? And that still doesn’t answer my question.”
 
“He called into my show,” Mic shrugs, smiling a little guiltily. He  better  feel guilty over this. “He’s so adorable, Eraser! And you were right, by the way. He really  is a hero fanboy. He was super excited about the autograph, it would’ve been cruel not to turn up after all that!”
 
“Did you get a name?” Aizawa demands, before realisation hits him like an oncoming train, “Wait, he didn’t use my hero name again, did he?”
 
Mic actually makes a bit of a face at that, “He didn’t,” he replies, somehow managing to make it sound like a bad thing. “Called himself  Deku,  if you can believe it. Assured me that he  was the vigilante, said he was thinking about getting himself a scarf.” At this, he aims a sly look towards Aizawa, before his expression sobers again. “A little concerning, isn’t it?”
 
Aizawa considers the kanji in the kid’s given name, the only one he really has for the vigilante... aside from his  own, anyway. “He told me his name was Izuku,” he says, fatefully. “First time we met.”
 
Mic grimaces. “Kids can be so cruel.”
 
Because what kind of a nickname is  useless? 
 
Nobody deserves to be called that, least of all his problem child.
 
Frustrating, maybe. Chaotic,  definitely, but useless?
 
Aizawa huffs, “Whatever. So you invited him for an autograph. How does he even know where we—”
 
“Hi Eraser!”
 
Aizawa slowly turns around, pain suddenly pulsing between his temples. 
 
Upon catching sight of both their faces, the kid brightens visibly, the rabbit ears sewn to the top of his green hoodie bobbing almost comically as he bounces on the balls of his feet. “Present Mic! You came!”
 
“I sure did, little listener!” Mic holds out a hand and the kid fearlessly skips over to high-five it. “I love the costume, bud, seriously! But where’s that scarf you said you were going to wear?”
 
The brat shrugs apologetically, “My friend’s still making it,” he waves flippantly. “She’s nearly finished, but trying to get it to float has been a trial. We’re almost there, though!”
 

 Trying to get it to float? 

 
Is he really—?
 
“That’s the spirit!” Mic says brightly, patting the kid on the head.
 

 Don’t encourage him. 

 
Aizawa nearly says it, too.
 
Except, after Mic’s revelation—maybe the kid  needs a bit of encouragement?
 
No.  No.  He is not encouraging a teenager to commit identity theft, no matter  what  his tragic past might be. That is absolutely  not happening. 
 
“You, um,” the kid shifts on his feet, suddenly nervous. “You said you’d sign my notebook for me?”
 
“I sure did!” Mic reaches into his jacket pocket. “How do you feel about gel pens, little listener? I’ve got strawberry, kiwi, and bubblegum scented with me tonight.”
 
Aizawa thinks there might actually be  stars in the kid’s eyes, “Would kiwi be okay? It’s just, green is my favourite colour!”
 
He’s gushing. 
 
The worst part about all this is that Mic is  gushing too. “That’s so awesome bud! I love green! It matches my eyes, you know.”
 
The boy gasps. “Mine too!”
 
A notebook is produced and a signature scribbled.
 
Aizawa mistakenly thinks that this is  the end.  That he can  go home, and sleep, and try his hardest to forget everything that happened tonight.
 
“Um, Eraser, could you maybe sign it too?”
 
“He hasn’t already?” Mic squawks.
 
“I would’ve asked before, but he keeps trying to arrest me,” the brat explains.
 
“You seem awfully sure that won’t be happening tonight,” Aizawa mutters drily.
 
“Oh, it won’t,” Mic assures, and Aizawa  would contradict him, but there’s a razor-sharp look of reckoning in his eyes that he’s hesitant to cross. “Eraser, strawberry or bubblegum?”
 
It must be karmic retribution when the kid pipes up with “Bubblegum!” at the same time Aizawa responds with a begrudging "Strawberry,” that would put even his least enthusiastic students to shame.
 
“Ha! Looks like it’s bubblegum,  Shouta!” Mic tosses him the pen. “You can get closer, kid. Eraserhead won’t try to  arrest you,  I promise.”
 
The kid still looks unsure.
 
Aizawa sighs, holding out a hand. “What he said, kid.”
 
The problem child scuttles forward, looking more skittish with every step, holding out the notebook. “It’s, uh, this page if that’s alright?”
 
And okay, Aizawa didn’t actually want to make the kid  scared  of him. It’s just that vigilantism is at best an illegal hobby, at worst a dangerous, illegal hobby, and he doesn’t want the boy’s life to be ruined over a misplaced sense of youthful justice. 
 
And  maybe,  he’s beginning to regret his earlier approach. 
 
The notebook has been opened to a double page spread displaying a drawing that, if he isn’t mistaken, is of  him—and it’s  good, and annotated apparently, and—
 
Oh. That’s not information that should be publicly known.
 
Aizawa taps the page. “Just  how do you know the limits of my quirk, Problem Child?”
 
“It’s just analysis,” Problem Child tells him, as though this is all perfectly normal, “I watch villain fights, and yours are always really cool. You fight practically quirkless!”
 
 Practically quirkless. What odd phrasing.
 
Aizawa shakes himself. It’s unnerving, but he doubts this information will fall into the wrong hands. The kid doesn’t seem like the type.  Still though… 
 
“Don’t go around spreading this kind of info,” he demands, signing the diagram hastily. “Especially any analysis you do on pros, kid. A lot of people could get hurt if the wrong villain gets hold of this.”
 
“Oh no!” the brat waves his hands frantically. “I would never, Eraser, I promise!”
 
“Hmph,” Aizawa huffs, pressing the notebook back into the child’s hands. “Isn’t it past your bedtime or something, kid?”
 
It’s honestly an understatement, given that the sun is due to rise in a few hours. He deliberately ignores the smirk spreading rapidly over Yamada’s face.
 
“Huh? Oh yeah, I probably should be getting home. Mum will be waking up soon. Thanks Eraser! Thank you, Present Mic! It was so cool to meet you!”
 
“It was awesome to meet you too!” If anyone  could  match the brat’s ridiculous levels of energy, Aizawa supposes that it  would  be Mic. “Can I get a  yeah for the road?”
 
“Yeah!” The kid throws a fist in the air before  vanishing.   
 
Again.
 
Probably his quirk.
 
“I can’t  believe  you tried to arrest that angel,” Mic’s onto him in a  flash.  “Oh my  god, Shouta, he’s so precious!”
 
Aizawa stabs a finger at him, “That,” he says, severely. “Is because you were here. He’s never that well behaved when it’s just me.”
 
“Well we know why  that is,” Mic cackles loudly. “You’re so totally his dad, Shou!” 
 
Aizawa scoffs. “No way. He’s such a problem child. Imagine dealing with that on a full-time basis.”
 
“You like him,” Mic goads. “I’ve known you  too long, Eraser. You can’t hide from me!”
 
“I don’t,” Aizawa protests, uselessly. If only he believed his own words.
 
“You know what I’m hearing from you?” Mic gets in his face, and Aizawa quickly regrets every life decision he’s ever made. “Denial, Shouta. This is  denial. ”
 
 
“You know, when you said you were going to make your own capture scarf, I was under the impression that you’d know how to use it.”
 
“I wanted to have one like yours, Eraser! There was no point if it didn’t function at least similarly.”
 
Aizawa scowls. “This isn’t how mine works—and that doesn’t matter anyway. You should know how it functions. You were the one who made it.”
 
“I actually wasn’t,” the problem child admits, gracelessly trying to free himself again. “My friend made it for me. It honestly would have been  fine,  it’s just that she gets a little trigger happy when she decides something needs…  improving. She likes her inventions to have her signature style you know? To build her brand.”
 
Aizawa eyes the blades currently pinning his problem child halfway up the wall. “You’re talking about the knives.”
 
“Yes,” the kid huffs, getting a little red in the face as he struggles to keep himself upright. “Among… other things. But everything else still works! It’s just that the knives are supposed to be retractable. I guess that mechanism broke though… but she still makes great support gear! You should give it a try sometime.”
 
“Sure,” Aizawa lies, making a mental note to keep his capture weapon as far away from this kid’s  friend as humanly possible. “You need some help, kid?”
 
“If you don’t mind,” the kid says meekly. “I… might be a little stuck.”
 
Aizawa arches an eyebrow. “And you can’t use your quirk to get down?”
 
There’s a pause, one that lasts a little too long, before the kid asks oddly, “You think I can use my quirk for this?”
 
“You’ve used it to get out of all sorts of other ridiculous situations. That vanishing act you pull, it’s some kind of teleportation quirk isn’t it? It can’t be invisibility, because your clothes disappear too,” Aizawa feels relatively confident in this explanation, because he can’t think of anything else it could be. He likes to think he’s a reasonable enough person that his theory has at least some merit to it.
 
“Ah,” the problem child hesitates. “Um, yes—yes that’s my quirk, but I can’t use it to get down because—” he glances around wildly as though someone in this deserted back-alley might jump in with a helpful explanation. “Because it doesn’t work when… I’m stuck to walls?”
 
“...I see.”
 
“I promise I can’t get down!” The kid cries, looking a little panicked at Aizawa’s dubious expression. “I really do need help, Eraser. Please don’t go!”
 
“Calm down, kid,” Aizawa soothes. “I wasn’t going to just leave you here.” Stuck to a freaking wall, of all things.
 
 How is he constantly getting himself into these situations?
 
Aizawa throws his scarf, hooking it onto a pole sticking out from under the guttering and hauling himself up the wall until he’s level with the child. He tugs experimentally at one of the blades lodged into the wall, and then considers the tangled mess of the copycat capture scarf—the kid wrapped firmly inside. “I think we’re going to have to cut it, problem child.”
 
The kid is visibly upset by this. “But—”
 
“There isn’t another way,” Aizawa interrupts, not unkindly. “I can’t untangle you without pulling those knives out, and they’re wedged too deep into the brickwork for that. Your friend did a pretty good job of making them extra sharp.”
 
“She’s like that,” the kid sniffles miserably.
 
Aizawa is used to having to cut his own weapon to get out of a tight fix, but he supposes that without a steady income from his vigilante work, it’s probably going to cost the child to get it repaired. “Alright,” he says sympathetically, pulling a short knife from his belt. “Hold onto me while I cut it, okay? It’s a long way to fall.”
 
It isn’t too far really, but the kid is a little too wrapped up to get into a good landing position, and a broken ankle is probably the last thing he needs. It’s the last thing  Aizawa needs too, because Recovery Girl gets a little testy about being woken up in the middle of the night for an impromptu healing session. She’ll probably be different if it’s a kid he’s dragging to her, but he’s received far too many lectures over the years about his recklessness in the field. 
 
“Okay,” the kid says, and reaches for Aizawa’s shoulder as the hero raises his knife, cutting cleanly through the white rope binding the child.
 
The kid almost falls, but he manages to hold on long enough for Aizawa to grab him, wrapping an arm around his middle for good measure. “Climb onto my back,” he grunts, the strain of holding the both of them up with one arm making him shake slightly. “Come on, kid.”
 
It’s difficult, but they manage to get into a position in which Aizawa is gripping his capture scarf with both hands, while the kid clings steadfastly to his back like a tiny, teenaged spider-monkey. Aizawa quickly climbs down, letting the kid drop to the ground, and then helping him untangle the mess of white rope.
 
The child eyes the end result forlornly. “She’s going to be so upset that you cut one of her babies in half.”
 
“...Right,” Aizawa decides not to give that one too much thought. “Are you going to be alright from here?”
 
The kid glances back up at him, “I’ll be okay,” he says, still sounding a little unhappy. “Thanks for helping me, Eraserhead.”
 
“Hey,” Aizawa says gently, reaching out to put a hand on the kid’s shoulder. “I have to cut my own weapon all the time. You’re trying to be like me, aren’t you? I think you’ve pretty much nailed it here, problem child.”
 
The smile he receives is almost blinding. “Thanks Eraser!” The kid chirps brightly, darting forward before Aizawa can say anything in return and wrapping his thin arms tightly around the hero’s middle. 
 
Aizawa startles, before relaxing. “You’re welcome, kid.” He pats the child’s head, “Maybe you should test the next scarf before you take it out with you. What do you think?”
 
The kid lets go, stepping back and grinning sheepishly at him. “I’ll do that,” he promises. “I’ll see you soon, Eraser!”
 
“See you, kid,” Aizawa gives his head another pat. “Try not to get in too much trouble, alright?”
 
The kid shrugs, “No promises.” He takes another step back, before vanishing into the shadows of the ill-lit alleyway.
 
Aizawa sighs, glancing up at the remainder of the kid’s capture weapon, fluttering ever so slightly in the soft night breeze. 
 
His kid is such a problem child.
 
 
It’s nine in the morning and Nezu is looking positively gleeful. That’s the only way Aizawa can think to describe him. 
 
It’s terrifying.
 
“Ah, Aizawa!” The principal waves him over.
 
“What’s got you so chipper?” Aizawa feigns boredom, his pulse thrumming rapidly as he blinks languidly, eyes half-lidded.
 
“You noticed!” Nezu exclaims in delighted surprise. “Tell me, do you know of anyone who goes by the name of Midori?”
 
Aizawa doesn’t. “No,” he hedges, because this could go in a number of directions, and about half of those will likely be present in his nightmares tonight. “I can’t say I do.”
 
“Neither do I,” Nezu admits. “I’ve combed the quirk registry database multiple times and I cannot find a single individual who fits the profile I’ve been building.”
 
“If you don’t mind my asking,” Aizawa is going to regret this line of questioning, he just knows it. “Exactly why  have you been building a profile on them?”
 
“Oh,” Nezu smiles. (Aizawa shudders, chilled, as though someone just walked over his grave.) “I’ve finally found a worthy chess opponent online! We’re currently tied for wins—though I have to admit, their play style is  ingenious. Thoroughly unlike anyone I’ve challenged before. I’ve been wanting to ask them to tea for quite a while now, but they’re proving exceptionally difficult to track down. Actually—” he pauses, before giving Aizawa a considering look. “Do you have hero work beyond your usual patrols at the moment?”
 
Aizawa does not like where this is going. “I don’t,” he says, unnecessarily. Nezu likely asked already knowing this.
 
“Perfect! Just what I need—some eyes on the street. I’m employing you.”
 
“I’m already employed by you.”
 
“Ah, but this is a private matter,” Nezu replies, sagely. “It wouldn’t be right of me to use UA resources in such a way.”
 
“You want me to interrogate a network of low-level crime syndicates about this chess prodigy?” Aizawa clarifies—because when Nezu says ‘eyes on the street,’ that is what he really means. “You do realise how shady this sounds, right?”
 
“Alas, I have already exhausted every legal avenue—there is nobody with that name who fits the parameters, so I have decided to broaden my reach to society’s underbelly.”
 
“And it couldn’t be a  pseudonym?”  Aizawa demands, mostly as a last ditch attempt to  get out of this. 
 
“I’ve already taken that into account,” Nezu sighs, perturbed. “A dead end, unfortunately. I suspect my parameters are missing something  vital. That is where you come in.”
 
“But—” Aizawa is grasping at straws now. “Doesn’t asking a UA teacher to do this violate UA's code of professional ethics?”
 
“In seven places,” Nezu agrees cheerily. “I’ll pay you double your hourly salary.”
 
Aizawa isn’t impressed. “I don’t need the money.”
 
“How about a favour then?” Nezu tilts his head. “You’ve been looking into the identity of that new vigilante, haven’t you? The one using your hero name as an alias?”
 
Aizawa has long given up on trying to figure out exactly  how  Nezu knows these things. He hasn’t even told the  police that he’s investigating the kid, for all that they’ve been soliciting his assistance with the capture. He has no doubt Nezu has been sitting on this information since the very beginning, waiting for exactly the right moment to leverage it.
 
“What of it?” Just because Nezu has him cornered fair and square doesn’t mean Aizawa is going to make it  easy for him.
 
“Oh, don’t be like that,” Nezu’s smile is disarming. “I had the thought that we could perhaps help each other, Eraserhead.”
